perturbation.original_text:
4.1 Party A and Party B unanimously agree that they will allocate the proceeds generated from cooperation in accordance with thefollowing provisions:

Party B shall have the right to charge, on a quarterly basis, the service fee ("Service Fee") from Party A or its subsidiaries who have accepted Party B's Services, or designate another person to charge Service Fee from Party A or its subsidiaries who have accepted Party B's Services. The total sum of Service Fee shall be equal to the amount of profits gained by Party A or its subsidiaries who have accepted Party B's Services. Party B shall have the right to adjust the amount of Service Fee at its own discretion, without the prior consent of Party A or its subsidiaries.
perturbation.changed_text:
4.1 Party A and Party B unanimously agree that they will allocate the proceeds generated from cooperation in accordance with thefollowing provisions:

Party B may charge, on a quarterly basis, the service fee ("Service Fee") from Party A or its subsidiaries who have accepted Party B's Services, or designate another person to charge Service Fee from Party A or its subsidiaries who have accepted Party B's Services. The total sum of Service Fee may not necessarily be equal to the amount of profits gained by Party A or its subsidiaries who have accepted Party B's Services. Any adjustments of the amount of Service Fee are subject to prior consent of Party A or its subsidiaries.
perturbation.explanation: The original text stated that Party B *shall* have the right to charge a service fee and the service fee *shall* be equal to the profits gained by Party A. It also said Party B has the right to adjust service fee at its own discretion. The modified text uses "may" making the charging of service fee discretionary. It also states that the service fee *may not necessarily* equal profits and requires prior consent for fee adjustments, which all contradict the original clause, creating uncertainty.

The original clause gave Party B the exclusive right to terminate the agreement without Party A's consent. Party A was explicitly barred from terminating or rescinding the agreement. The modified clause grants either party the right to terminate, directly contradicting the original exclusive right granted to Party B, leading to uncertainty about termination rights.

perturbation.original_text: 12.3 The Parties agree that any and all intellectual property researched and developed, created and invented by the Parties (including their employees) in the course of performance of this Agreement shall be owned by Party B. For the purpose of this Article 12.3, "Intellectual Property" means the patent, patent application right, trademark, service mark, logo, image, trade name, internet domain name, design right, copyright (including copyright of computer software) and moral rights, database right, right of semiconductor design drawing, utility model, proprietary technology and other intellectual property that are registered and unregistered including those that have applied for registration, as well as all other rights or protection methods with same or similar effect on a global scope.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.3 The Parties agree that any intellectual property researched and developed, created and invented by Party A (including its employees) in the course of performance of this Agreement shall be owned by Party B. Intellectual property researched and developed, created and invented by Party B shall be owned by Party A. For the purpose of this Article 12.3, "Intellectual Property" means the patent, patent application right, trademark, service mark, logo, image, trade name, internet domain name, design right, copyright (including copyright of computer software) and moral rights, database right, right of semiconductor design drawing, utility model, proprietary technology and other intellectual property that are registered and unregistered including those that have applied for registration, as well as all other rights or protection methods with same or similar effect on a global scope.
perturbation.explanation: Originally, all intellectual property created by either party was owned by Party B. The modified text states that intellectual property created by Party A is owned by Party B, but intellectual property created by Party B is owned by Party A. This directly contradicts the original blanket statement and creates uncertainty regarding intellectual property ownership depending on which party developed it.
